entry.title: Hacking the Internet of Things
entry.content:
When connecting devices to the web you face different questions. One is for sure to understand which is the best electronic you can use. In Lelylan we are experimenting physical nodes, devices that defines a set of web services to connect your house to the web.

To build a physical node you can use different hardware solutions varying on computational power, wireless capability and budget. The only required thing is the ability to bild a web server that accepts and send request over the internet.


Arduino

Description: open-source electronics prototyping platform based on flexible, easy-to-use hardware and software. It's intended for artists, designers, hobbyists, and anyone interested in creating interactive objects or environments. It can be connected to the internet using ethernet, zigbee, wifi and more.

Good: big community, open-source hw, cheap, documentation.

Bad: computational power.

Prices: base ~ $30, ethernet ~ $60, wifi ~ $120 and zigbee ~ $75 (including XBee Antenna).


Nanode

Description: open source Arduino-like board that has in-built web connectivity. It connects to a range of wireless, wired and ethernet interfaces. It allows you to develop web based sensor and control systems, giving you web access to six analogue sensor lines and six digital I/O lines. Nanode was designed with hacking in mind.

Good: built-in web connectivity, open-source hw, really cheap, arduino compatible.

Bad: computational power, documentation.

Prices: ethernet ~ $40 and wireless ~ $48 (uses RFM12B wireless transceiver).


openPICUS

Description: defines itself as Internet freedom for your things, control and communication for electronic devices. A standalone hardware and software platform for embedded applications to interact via web, email or messages with simple sensors or complex electronic equipment.

Good: built-in web connectivity, cheap, good documentation, support.

Bad: computational power, development windows oriented.

Price: wifi ~ $90.


Netduino

Description: open-source electronics platform using the .NET Micro Framework. With Netduino, the world of microcontroller programming can be easily aproached by people programming with .NET. Netduino is designed to enable both personal projects and sophisticated commercial endeavors.

Good: open-source hw, cheap, documentation, arduino compatible, .NET programming.

Bad: computational power.

Prices: base ~ $35, ethernet ~ $60, wifi ~ $120 and zigbee ~ $75 (including XBee Antenna).


Libellium Waspmote

Description: sensor device developers oriented. It works with different communicaction protocols (ZigBee, wifi, Bluetooth and GPRS) and frequencies (2.4GHz, 868MHz, 900MHz) and create links up to 12Km. Using the hibernate low power mode (0.7uA) it can save battery energy when not transmitting and be able to work even for years. Waspmote is compatible with more than 50 sensors and its open source IDE makes really easy to start working with it

Good: documentation, solid, support, radio borads, sensors boards, over the air programming.

Bad: computational power, expensive.

Price: zigbee ~ $180, wifi ~ $200. The price catalog can be found here


Considerations

This is an opinioned list with the best solutions out there. If you think we are missing a good one you can head over to Hacker News to add it.

This is the first part of a two articles serie. In the next one we will be featuring hardware solutions with more computational power like Raspberry Pi and Panda Board, which are perfect to define hubs that communicates with the web and all devices in your house.

entry.title: Dreaming the Connected Home
entry.content:
You are sitting in front of your TV set, while watching the last fresh action movie. The hero bombs some bad guy, while your iPad is off, near the couch. Suddenly it turns on, and 3 notifications get your attention.

  1. The air conditioning system from the bedroom says it is scheduled to warm the room in 10 minutes. The movie you are watching on your tv-set would last another hour, so it is asking you "do you want me to be suspended for about 40 minutes more?"
  2. The coffee machine sends a message saying "ready to prepare coffee, tomorrow morning at 7.00am. There is just two shots left on".
  3. The 5 sensors around the house sent their hourly set of measures: 20 degrees, 30% humidity, lights off, noise level outside about normal value.

You answer to the air condition system in a few clicks, then you forward the message from coffee machine to your personal office email (remind tomorrow to buy coffee). And keep enjoying the movie. Do you like this story? Do you know it is possible at a very cheap price? Let’s dig more in.

First case: a scary future.

Imagine a future where the Connected Home of our dream rest on "Manufacturer-Oriented" devices. Your devices are someway working smoothly through Internet, each one sending messages you are not allowed to access, owned by a different company (each manufacturer plans, builds and manage a different system, code and instructions set).

Your neighbour has found easily your passwords, because you need to create and use so many of them, so they all look similar. Same password you submit to connect on facebook, and your neighbour’s fake online dating service. And your neighbour hates you, because you earn more than him. He just plays with you, turning on and off the air conditioning during the night, to give you some hard time. And the coffee machine spilled too much coffee out, getting everything dirty.

When you notice what’s going on, you got fever twice, but finally the new password keeps him out of your house.

Second case: the house at your service.

Imagine a a future where the Internet of Things is built with privacy concerns in mind, only for you. Your devices are working smoothly, through Internet, each one sending a standard message to your account, which you read on mobile, on the tablet, on computer. Anywhere.

You enjoy your movie. You get comfortable with the all-tech-house system. And you praise those guys who spent their time creating beautiful applications for your china-cheap devices, instead of sitting idle watching their sf-favorite movie (you know, those star trek, matrix, star wars stories).

How Is It Going To Happen and what You should do.

At Lelylan we are studying how to build some application to let all your devices play and talk easily, without the need to spend one cents more! If you want to speed it up, here is what you can do.

  1. Leave a comment, sharing your experience. Do you have already some devices? Are you planning to buy some in the next future? Which devices do you want to connect?
  2. Say aloud your ideas about How You Would Like It, if Tomorrow You Get It. Funny stories required!
  3. Check with friends how much they’ll envy you, as soon as you get it.

It’s all about you.

More you do, more you get. Thanks a lot.

entry.title: Simplifying the Connected Home
entry.content:
One reason home automation is not getting off the ground is complexity. I'm sure most of the experts working in the fields deny this, but they are lying :) Why?

  1. We need them to build the connected house.
  2. If we want to extend the connected house we need to learn a protocol. Trying to understand all of those 0x#09fa! codes will take a loooooong time.
  3. Everyday a new standard pops up, as the solution to all our pains. Actually, no de facto standard exists today.

The raising question is: how can we improve this situation?
The answer is: simple, using the web.

Really. Think at a reason not to do it. It's easy, extensible, interoperable and full of people developing cool ideas every single day on top of it.

Using a platform based on a set of REST web services enable you to access all home automation resources (devices, locations, people and more). Every device is mapped to a unique URI which will provide control over it. When such a connection is done, technological limitations disappear and devices become identifiable only through their functionalities. No more headache, just easy stuff.

As you can see on the sample pics a URI can be used to monitor and control everything. You don't need anything else to build your connected house. In this way everyone working in the web can start working on home automation creating new cool solutions.

entry.title: Home automation: experts' point of view
entry.content:
Our last article explained why home automation isn't working today, at least for us. The article was deliberately provoking, and we received lots of feedback. Some were good, some were not, but all of them taught us something. In this article we decided to sum up some of the most interesting thoughts, to remember how some experts are approaching home automation.

Group #1. Home automation is my precious.

I Don't think Automation Sucks.
I think Automation is exactly where it should be.
Otherwise the costs would drop, the profits would
follow and the work load would increase...

Mr. Gollum

For some experts the main goal is profit. They do not care about user experience, services or innovation. They only care about themselves. Their perfect world is the one where everything is closed and under their control, so they can become rich. They are the winners, absolutely.

Group #2. Homeowners are a nightmare.

As long as you are dealing with "A Home Owner" you get comments such as; "it's too big", it's too small", it's too fat", it's too thin", "it looks funny", "I can't read the text", "isn't there a different color", "why doesn't it do everything"...

Mr. Nightmare

I think this problem arise when you lack two basic things.

  1. Know what you do. Know your sector and the solutions you can offer. If you don't, clients will start asking for any possible idea they have in mind.
  2. Start saying no. The secret of getting half a product instead of a half-ass product is saying no. If people complain when you don't adopt their ideas, remind them why they liked the home automation system you proposed in the first place. I know this is not easy, but it will pay back.

Group #3. You can not play with me, you are not smart.

Home automation needs a lot of time, effort and knowledge and it's a challenge where you can't succed if you don't have the technical knowledge, pragmatic sensibility to deal with end-users and a strong project management skills...

Mr. Smart

I didn't know home automation was like getting a degree in astrophysics. For sure home automation is not like playing with Lego (not yet) but if we keep making home automation something so difficult to use, we will never see a connected house in our lives. Wouldn't be better if every single person who has a specific knowledge could improve domotics? We think so.

Conclusions

Of course, there were other answers making up other groups, even interesting ones. However, these were the ones that made us think the most. It seems that most experts in the field of home automation have a limited way of thinking, referring only to the existing market. Our dream, the birth of an open home automation system for everyone, appears to be far this way, and this is the reason we are here, a passionate need to change the rules.

entry.title: Why home automation sucks
entry.content:
When we talk about Lelylan, most of the people just tell us that domotics already exists.

As we try to enjoy our time around, we reply with a simple question: how many of you have a domotics system, today? The answer is always the same, nobody. To highlight this, it was fun when during a presentation in front of almost 100 people just one hand raised up, clarifying that his domotics system didn't really work.

It's true, lots of companies have been working on home automation for many years. Some of them are well-known names like Creston, Control4 and AMX, but there is no real market. As there are so few domotics houses, this field looks like a dream for many of us. At this point, the correct question is: why home automation sucks so much nowadays!?

People tend to think that the cause for the low domotics penetration is price. This is both true and false. Actual domotics systems are quite expensive, but like all technologies, when they start to spread, costs start to get lower and lower. So why, why home automation is not a reality?

The real problem are the existing domotics companies. They create devices that are not able to speak to each other, trying in this way to keep their market share. The consequences are the impossibility for devices such as lights, appliances, security and alarm systems, gas and smoke sensors, multimedia systems, heating systems to communicate with each other, higher complexities, fewer services, higher prices and more importantly lot of confusion for the final user.

Thinking at home automation as companies do today, will not last long. Lelylan and new Internet of Things related Companies will change the way we think at home automation.

Let everyone experiment new services, remove complexities, make devices communicate and teach people what home automation really means.

Mr. Lelylan

If you think home automation sucks, join us now. We envision a future where our houses will be the ones we have dreamed when we where child. Don't you love this?
